H0.text: Wind is the source of energy that a power plant most likely uses to convert chemical energy into electricity.

H1.text: Sunlight is the source of energy most likely used by a power plant that converts chemical energy into electricity.

H2.text: Fossil fuel is the source of energy that a power plant most likely uses to convert chemical energy into electricity.

H3.text: Tidal waves are the source of energy most likely used by a power plant that uses chemical energy to produce electricity.

A4.text: Fossil fuel power stations are thermal power stations that burn fossil fuel, such as coal, oil, or natural gas, to produce electricity.

A5.text: Most thermal power stations in the world use fossil fuel, outnumbering nuclear, geothermal, biomass, or concentrated solar power plants.
